title: Top Career Opportunities in Metallurgical Engineering
author: CDC Team
summary: Explore the diverse career paths available for metallurgical engineers in today's industrial landscape, from research to management roles.
content: Metallurgical Engineering presents a wide range of career opportunities both in India and internationally, spanning industries, research, and academia. In India, metallurgists are employed in core sectors such as steel, mining, and manufacturing with companies like Tata Steel, SAIL, JSW, Hindalco, and Vedanta, as well as in public sector undertakings and government organizations including ISRO, BARC, DRDO, and IOCL, often through competitive exams like GATE. The private sector also offers roles in automotive, aerospace, electronics, and defense manufacturing, where metallurgists work in areas such as process engineering, quality control, product development, and failure analysis. Research and academic positions are available at IITs, NITs, IISc, and CSIR labs, with growing interest in emerging fields like energy materials, biomaterials, and additive manufacturing. Internationally, opportunities exist in both industry and academia, with graduates pursuing higher studies and jobs in countries like the USA, Germany, Canada, and Australia in top universities and global companies such as Boeing, ArcelorMittal, and Shell. These roles often require specialization in areas like corrosion engineering, materials informatics, sustainable metallurgy, and advanced manufacturing. Certifications such as PE, P.Eng, or CEng may be needed depending on the country. With strong technical knowledge, hands-on skills, research exposure, and familiarity with computational tools and global standards, metallurgical engineers can build rewarding careers contributing to advancements in aerospace, renewable energy, medical devices, and beyond.

title: When Enthusiasm Overflows: The Bittersweet Surge in COMPOSIT 2025 Participation
author: COMPOSIT Team
summary: COMPOSIT 2025 witnessed a dramatic surge in participation, exposing infrastructure and logistical challenges that call for urgent expansion in future editions.
content: COMPOSIT 2025, the flagship materials science symposium of IIT Kharagpur, witnessed an unprecedented surge in participation this year—an outcome that, while celebratory in numbers, revealed the growing pains of success. Historically known for its high-impact guest lectures, engaging workshops, and cutting-edge competitions, the fest has steadily evolved into a national magnet for students, researchers, and industry professionals. However, the dramatic hike in footfall this year caught organizers off guard. Accommodation shortages, long queues, and overwhelmed event venues led to concerns about safety, logistics, and the overall experience of attendees. While the vibrant enthusiasm for materials science is certainly a victory for the community, this year's turnout also served as a wake-up call: great interest must be matched with even greater infrastructure. The organizing team's passion was palpable, but 2025's tragic overflow underscored the urgent need to scale up resources and rethink event management for future editions. COMPOSIT's growing popularity is undeniable—now it's time to ensure the festival's heart doesn't get lost in the crowd.

title: Forging Global Leaders: How IIT Kharagpur's Metallurgical Department Shapes Change-Makers
author: SME Team
summary: IIT Kharagpur's MME alumni are transforming global industries and governance, from Google's CEO to top scientific leaders in India.
content: The Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering (MME) at IIT Kharagpur has long stood as a pillar of academic excellence, shaping individuals who go on to redefine industries and institutions. Dr. Shrikumar Banerjee, a proud alumnus from the 1967 batch and former member of the Board of Governors, was recently honored for his enduring contributions to science and engineering in India. Along similar lines, Dr. Samir Venkatpati Kamat (B.Tech 1985) has ascended to the role of Director at the Defence Metallurgical Research Laboratory (DMRL), symbolizing the seamless flow from rigorous academic roots to national leadership. Meanwhile, Prof. P.K. Sen's selection as Chairman of the Technical Committee at the Bureau of Energy Efficiency under the Ministry of Power highlights the growing influence of metallurgical minds in policymaking. Perhaps the most globally recognized name on this list is Sundar Pichai (B.Tech 1993), whose leadership as CEO of Google reflects the department's far-reaching impact beyond metallurgy. These stories, woven together, underscore how IIT Kharagpur's MME alumni continue to leave indelible marks across academia, industry, governance, and global technology.

title: Academic Luminaries: The Faculty Driving Breakthroughs at IIT Kharagpur's MME Department
author: News Team
summary: Faculty at IIT-KGP's MME department are driving metallurgical innovation, earning national accolades and producing high-impact research.
content: At the heart of IIT Kharagpur's MME department is a vibrant community of faculty who serve as mentors, innovators, and nationally recognized thought leaders. With over 90 publications per year and a whopping ₹5940 lakhs in sponsored project funding over the past five years, the department continues to set benchmarks in academic productivity. Notable figures like Prof. S.K. Roy have been conferred Honorary Membership by the Indian Institute of Metals, an acknowledgment of decades of impactful teaching and research. Prof. Rahul Mitra added another feather to the department's cap with his win of the esteemed NMD Award in the Metal Science category. Furthermore, Prof. Gour Gopal Roy was named 'Metallurgist of the Year' by the Ministry of Steel for his pioneering work in rotary furnace processing of iron ore and coal fines. Sharing that accolade is Prof. Jyotsna Dutta Majumdar, whose cutting-edge materials research has transformed both the academic and industrial spheres. These accolades reflect a culture of excellence that transcends classrooms and laboratories, positioning the MME department as a national hub for metallurgical innovation.

title: Young Innovators: Student Success Stories from the Metallurgical Frontier
author: News Team
summary: Students of IIT-KGP's MME department are gaining national recognition, proving the department's dedication to nurturing next-gen talent.
content: Innovation and brilliance don't just emerge from the faculty at IIT Kharagpur's MME department—they're woven into the DNA of its students. That spirit was recently celebrated as Shri Arijit Mitra, a Dual Degree student, and Mr. Kunwar Akash Singh, a B.Tech student, were jointly awarded the prestigious IIM Vidya Bharathi Prize for their exemplary academic performance and research contributions. These accolades reflect more than personal achievement; they signify the department's unwavering commitment to grooming the next generation of metallurgical scientists and engineers. In parallel, the department's record of completing 43 consultancy projects worth ₹290 lakhs in the past five years serves as a powerful testament to its real-world relevance. At IIT Kharagpur, excellence is a shared pursuit—from students and scholars to researchers and industry collaborators—forming a unique ecosystem where ideas are not just born but nurtured into transformative breakthroughs.

title: AI in Action: Kanika Guleria’s Internship Experience at Fidelity Investments
author: Kanika Guleria
summary: AI Engineering Intern at Fidelity, developing ML-driven decision tools, analyzing behavioral data, and integrating AI into user-facing platforms.

questions.question: Hello! My name is Omkar Prajapati Today we have with us an AI Engineering Intern at Fidelity Investments, who will share her journey through the CDC process, the internship experience, and tips for aspirants. Welcome! Can you briefly introduce your current role?
questions.answer: Hello! I’m currently interning at Fidelity Investments as an AI Engineering Intern. My work involves designing intelligent systems that support decision-making through machine learning and data-driven techniques. I work on building interactive applications, analyzing behavioral data, and developing tools to evaluate and improve user performance. Besides that, I also contribute to backend development, data processing pipelines, and integrate AI models into end-user platforms.

questions.question: Could you walk us through your CDC experience and how the interviews went?
questions.answer: The CDC process was quite intense and exhausting, but ultimately rewarding. I found out I was shortlisted the night before, around 9–10 PM, and had to report by 8:30 AM the next morning. About 54 candidates were initially shortlisted. My first round was around 12:30 PM, after which we had a lunch break. Around 3:30 PM, we were told that 11 candidates had cleared the first round. My second round was at 6 PM, and all second-round candidates also appeared for the HR round around 7:30 PM. Results were out by 8:30 PM, and 4 candidates were selected. The entire process spanned over 12 hours, testing both patience and stamina.

questions.question: That sounds intense! Do you remember what kind of questions they asked?
questions.answer: Definitely. The questions covered Python basics, key concepts from my CV, and several ML/DL concepts. Since I had a finance-related project on my resume, they asked me to build a basic financial model to predict stock movements using historical data. There was also a SQL question that I had to solve on a blackboard — it tested not just correctness, but clarity of explanation under pressure.

questions.question: Did you face any difficulty being from the Metallurgical and Materials Engineering department?
questions.answer: Department bias and CG-based shortlisting are real issues for non-CS branches like ours. I was fortunate to have strong, focused projects aligned with data roles, so shortlisting wasn’t a major issue for me. But I know it can be a roadblock for many, despite their skill levels.

questions.question: How much do positions of responsibility (PORs) and internships matter?
questions.answer: PORs matter more for roles like consulting, where leadership and communication skills are key. But for tech and core profiles, what truly matters is the depth and impact of your experience, whether through internships, projects, or even well-done PORs. It’s not about the title — it’s about what you’ve done.

questions.question: When did you start preparing for CDC and how did you go about it?
questions.answer: I began a few months prior, focusing mainly on DSA and programming. I also participated in the JPMorgan Quantitative Finance Mentorship program, which gave me exposure to core math, finance, and probability. Alongside that, I made sure to polish every skill and concept reflected on my CV.

questions.question: And what about interview preparation?
questions.answer: I made notes for every single line on my CV — what I did, why I did it, and what impact it had. I also practiced mock interviews with seniors, which helped a lot with articulation and confidence. Having a well-structured self-introduction ready helped me set the right tone from the beginning and transition smoothly into technical discussions.

questions.question: How much domain knowledge is necessary?
questions.answer: It depends on the role. For data and technical roles, strong fundamentals in Python, SQL, ML, and Statistics are expected. If your resume includes domain-specific elements like finance, you should know the basics. But overall, what matters most is how well you understand and can explain your experiences.

questions.question: What about DSA and CS fundamentals?
questions.answer: DSA is critical — most shortlisting tests rely on it. You should be confident in core topics like arrays, trees, graphs, and DP. As for CS fundamentals, OOPs is commonly asked, while DBMS, OS, and Networks help but aren't always necessary unless explicitly relevant.

questions.question: Could you share some preparation resources and how to use the summer effectively?
questions.answer: For DSA, I used LeetCode, InterviewBit, and GeeksforGeeks. For SQL, StrataScratch and HackerRank are great. For ML and stats, I relied on Andrew Ng’s course, StatQuest, and projects using Kaggle datasets. The summer break is the perfect time to explore. Build projects, review past work, and strengthen weak areas. Avoid trying to learn everything — double down on your strengths and make them interview-ready.

questions.question: What does a good CV look like in your opinion?
questions.answer: A good CV tells a coherent story. It doesn’t have to be long — even a few well-executed and deeply understood projects can make it strong. Clarity, impact, and authenticity matter far more than volume.

questions.question: Any suggestions on reaching out for off-campus internships?
questions.answer: Be brief, polite, and specific when messaging. Don’t be discouraged by a lack of replies — persistence matters more than immediate success.

questions.question: What was your backup plan?
questions.answer: My primary interest was AI and Data, so my backups were Data Analyst or Product Analyst roles, which require more problem-solving than heavy coding. I was also comfortable pivoting to Quant roles due to my finance-related work.

questions.question: With just a month left before placements, how should students approach their prep?
questions.answer: Focus on strengthening what you already know — don’t try to learn completely new topics now. Have a few target companies in mind, study their past patterns, and tailor your prep accordingly. Some are DSA-heavy, others emphasize SQL or ML. That focused preparation helps you stay motivated.

tips: Identify target companies – Tailor your prep based on each company's focus (DSA, SQL/ML, case studies).
Start early – Even a month of focused preparation can have a big impact.
Talk to seniors – Leverage their insights to streamline your effort.
Stay honest – Be truthful in interviews and your resume.
Don't panic – Ignore the noise, and stay consistent with your own journey
Stay motivated – Focusing on specific goals helps maintain momentum, especially when general prep feels overwhelming.

title: Breaking Barriers – Abhinav Karade’s Journey to a Data Engineering Role at NPCI
author: Abhinav Karade
summary: Abhinav Karade, a third-year undergraduate student in Metallurgical and Materials Engineering at IIT Kharagpur, shares his inspiring journey of securing a Data Engineering internship at the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI). From facing challenges as a non-circuital department student to acing online assessments and interviews, Abhinav's story is a valuable guide for students aiming to succeed in CDC recruitment. He emphasizes the importance of consistent DSA practice, building a standout CV, and staying calm and focused during preparation.

questions.question: Could you introduce yourself and describe your role at NPCI?
questions.answer: I’m a third-year UG student from MME, IIT Kharagpur, and I interned at NPCI through CDC in the Data Engineering domain. I worked on integrating LLMs, large databases, and modern web interfaces with MLOps practices. I focused on building data pipelines, automating deployments, and maintaining production-grade AI systems.

questions.question: What was your overall CDC experience like, including online assessments and interviews?
questions.answer: The process had two OAs, although I gave only one. It included DSA (Trees, Linked Lists), ML/NN MCQs, Aptitude, and English reasoning. I was shortlisted based on my OA and CV and had a single 35–40 minute interview.

questions.question: Can you recall any specific interview questions?
questions.answer: The interview started with an intro and tech discussion. I was asked an array-based DSA problem, OOPS topics like Virtual Functions and Abstraction, ML algorithms like Random Forest, and a deep dive into one project from my resume.

questions.question: What challenges did you face as an MME student during CDC?
questions.answer: Many SDE companies don't open for non-circuital branches. Even when allowed, shortlisting often favors circuital departments. Hence, a strong CV, CGPA (7.5+), and relevant experience are key. PORs matter less for tech roles.

questions.question: Did you have any prior internships, and how important are they?
questions.answer: I didn’t, but I participated in competitions. Internships (tech/research) help but aren’t mandatory. Good ranks in Unstop or tech GCs add value. FTPs and research stints are solid alternatives.

questions.question: When did you start preparing, and what was your strategy?
questions.answer: I began during summer break. Focused on consistent DSA (especially DP and graphs) with LeetCode, Striver’s A2Z Sheet, and Codeforces. Prepared CV thoroughly and practiced HR questions from articles.

questions.question: How did you specifically prepare for your interviews?
questions.answer: Practiced DSA on LeetCode/InterviewBit. Reviewed OOPS and DBMS. Prepared for project-based questions. Did mock interviews with friends and revised HR questions.

questions.question: Could you share some preparation resources or tips for juniors?
questions.answer: Striver’s A2Z Sheet, LeetCode, Codeforces, AlgoZenith. Use summer break wisely to get started early.

questions.question: What makes a strong CV for SDE roles?
questions.answer: Projects matter most. Use trending technologies and include ML/DL. Add internships/hackathons. Review with peers/seniors to catch mistakes.

questions.question: With only a month left before CDC, what should students focus on?
questions.answer: Practice DSA daily. Give CP contests. Revise OOPS and DBMS regularly. Persistence is key.

questions.question: Any final advice for your juniors?
questions.answer: Take consistent steps. Don’t be discouraged by rejections. Focus on learning and improving. Stay calm and results will follow.

tips: Start DSA preparation early and solve problems consistently.
Participate in CP contests to improve problem-solving speed.
Use summer break to build projects and strengthen your resume.
Mock interviews with friends can boost confidence.
Keep a calm and positive mindset – focus on learning, not outcomes.

title: Navigating CDC as an MME Student: Preparation, Challenges, and Tips for Data/SDE Roles
author: Kamal Bajoria
summary: An MME student shares their CDC journey, including the NPCI selection process, preparation strategies for DSA and ML, and challenges faced as a non-circuital branch student. Key insights include the importance of consistent effort, building unique projects, and not being discouraged by rejections. The student emphasizes smart preparation over the summer, using targeted resources like Striver’s sheet and Krish Naik, and staying confident even with limited time left.

questions.question: Could you briefly describe your role?
questions.answer: I am currently working as a Data Engineering intern at NPCI. My role involved working with data, including tasks related to AI & ML, software development, and handling databases. It was a technical role requiring understanding of both data science and software concepts.

questions.question: How was your CDC experience?
questions.answer: For most companies, there is a CV shortlisting round (sometimes based on CGPA), followed by an online assessment (OA), and then the final interview. For NPCI, there were 2 rounds—one OA and one technical interview. The OA had sections on ML MCQs, aptitude, English essay writing, and 2 medium DSA problems. The technical interview lasted about 30 minutes and focused on OOPs, pointers, DBMS, and DSA. They asked for the logic, not full code. Some basic ML questions were also asked.

questions.question: Did you face any problems as an MME student?
questions.answer: Yes. Being from a non-circuital branch, many companies don’t open for us. Some core companies like TATA also prefer Mechanical students. Additionally, some companies have a minimum CGPA cutoff (generally above 8.0). Apart from this, there weren’t major issues.

questions.question: How much do PORs and internships matter?
questions.answer: PORs help in overall development—time management, communication, networking—but are not essential for SDE or data roles. Similarly, internships can give an edge but not having one isn’t a deal-breaker.

questions.question: When did you start preparing for CDC? What was your preparation process like?
questions.answer: I started in my 2nd year. I had interest in both software development and AI/ML, so I pursued both consistently. For DSA, I followed Striver's sheet. For AI & ML, I followed Krish Naik and Jovian.

questions.question: How did you prepare for the interviews?
questions.answer: Strong problem-solving skills are a must. Be ready with optimized solutions. Also, be clear with everything mentioned in your CV—interviewers often ask deep questions on those topics.

questions.question: What domain knowledge is required?
questions.answer: You don’t need to know everything. Just be clear with the important concepts and terms relevant to your domain.

questions.question: How much DSA is required?
questions.answer: It varies by company. Some ask easy to medium-level questions, while others may ask medium to hard-level DSA problems.

questions.question: How much CS fundamentals are required?
questions.answer: Again, this depends on the company. Some emphasize OOPs, DBMS, OS, etc., while others focus more on DSA or project work.

questions.question: Could you share some resources for preparation? How should one start their preparation? How to utilize the summer break?
questions.answer: For DSA, follow Striver's sheet. For ML, use resources like Krish Naik, CampusX, and Jovian. Use your summer break to prepare regularly and stay consistent.

questions.question: What is a good CV in your opinion?
questions.answer: Include unique projects and try new technologies. Avoid copying projects. A standout CV has originality and relevance to the roles applied for.

questions.question: What was your backup profile?
questions.answer: My main focus was on SDE roles. However, I had experience in both data and core subjects, so I kept my options open.

questions.question: With only a month in hand, what should one focus on? Should one have any target companies? Any extra tips?
questions.answer: Focus on revising everything you’ve studied so far. Confidence comes from preparation. Don’t let early rejections affect you. Stay patient, be consistent, and keep going.

tips: Use your summer break wisely to prepare and build consistency.
Focus on original projects to make your CV stand out.
Don't be discouraged by early rejections—keep trying.
Follow structured resources like Striver’s sheet and Krish Naik.

title: Lavesh Kadam’s CDC Journey to Honeywell: A Data Role from a Non-Circuit Branch
author: Lavesh Kadam
summary: Lavesh Kadam, a dual degree MME student, landed a Data Engineering internship at Honeywell via CDC. He built a strong profile with research internships, solid projects, and consistent prep in DSA, ML, and stats. His advice: stay confident and trust your preparation.

questions.question: Briefly describe your role.
questions.answer: My role is Data Engineering Intern at Honeywell. To be specific, it is a mix of data engineering and data science tasks.

questions.question: How was your overall CDC experience?
questions.answer: I got shortlisted for three companies. I wasn’t selected in the first two, but got into Honeywell. The process had one OA with 4 questions — 3 DSA problems and one Python-based string problem. After clearing that, there was one technical interview focused on my CV. It was panel-based and had in-depth questions about my projects and internships.

questions.question: Do you remember any specific questions from your interviews?
questions.answer: Yes, the interviewer asked me to explain each project in detail, especially my deep learning projects. I was asked about ML models, evaluation metrics, and specific methods mentioned in my resume. The interview was 20–25 minutes long.

questions.question: What challenges did you face as an MME student during CDC?
questions.answer: Some companies prefer circuital branches, and many have a CGPA cutoff (above 8.0 is safe). Internships and strong CVs help more than PORs in data roles. MME students have to work harder to get shortlists, but interviews depend on individual performance.

questions.question: Did you have any prior internships? If yes, how did they help? How can one approach the same?
questions.answer: Yes, I had two research internships. They added value to my CV. Cold-mailing to professors and exploring FTP or projects at IIT KGP are good ways to get internships.

questions.question: When did you begin preparing for CDC? What was your overall preparation strategy?
questions.answer: I started profile building after 2nd year and serious CDC prep in the 6th semester. Focused on Python, ML, and stats. Took MLFA, got research internships, did Leetcode, brushed up SQL, and joined tech competitions like TechGC and OpenIIT.

questions.question: How did you specifically prepare for interviews?
questions.answer: Focused on knowing my CV thoroughly. Revised projects, stats, and did mock interviews with friends. Prepared short project stories. Also spoke to seniors who interned at Honeywell.

questions.question: Could you share some preparation resources or tips for juniors? How should one start their prep? How to make the most of the summer break?
questions.answer: Start with Python, pandas, numpy, matplotlib, then ML and stats. Use CampusX, Krish Naik, CodeEmporium, StatQuest, 3Blue1Brown. Do DSA and get a research internship or build projects during summer.

questions.question: What, in your opinion, makes a strong CV?
questions.answer: Unique and impactful projects, real-world use cases, results-driven points with numbers. Avoid generic projects. Be confident about everything on your CV. Achievements and competitions help.

questions.question: Did you have a backup profile or alternative plan?
questions.answer: Yes, I had three CVs — two for data roles (one tailored for FinTech) and one for core. It’s good to be prepared with backups, especially for non-circuit branches.

questions.question: With only a month left before CDC, what should students focus on?
questions.answer: Focus on OA prep and CV prep. Practice DSA (Striver’s Sheet, Leetcode Medium), revise aptitude and puzzles, ML/DL/stats concepts, and be confident about your projects.

questions.question: Any final tips or advice you’d like to share?
questions.answer: Rejections and delays are normal — don’t panic. Keep preparing and stay confident. I got my offer in mid-September. Trust the process. You’ll get through — and even if not, it’s not the end. All the best!

tips: Start early with Python, ML, and DSA to build a strong base.
Cold-mailing is an effective way to get research internships.
Be confident and deeply familiar with everything on your CV.
Use summer break wisely for projects, internships, or learning new skills.

title: From Metallurgy to Machine Learning: Rathin Ghosh’s Journey to NPCI’s Market Innovation Team
author: Rathin Ghosh
summary: An MME student shares their enriching internship experience at NPCI’s Market Innovation team in Mumbai, where they worked on machine learning models for detecting UPI frauds. The journey covers CDC prep, domain focus in AI/ML, practical advice on interviews, DSA, CV building, and staying confident through the selection process.

questions.question: Brief description of your current role at your internship.
questions.answer: I am currently an intern at NPCI in the Data Science & Statistics team, working on ML models for detecting fraud in UPI payments.

questions.question: How was your CDC experience? (OAs and interviews)
questions.answer: There were two tests and one online interview. The questions were mostly CV-based, especially around my FTP on non-linear optimization for fraud detection.

questions.question: Do you remember any questions from your interviews?
questions.answer: Yes, they mostly asked questions related to my FTP project as it was relevant to the role.

questions.question: Did you face any problems as a MME student?
questions.answer: No, I did not face any difficulty specifically due to my department.

questions.question: How much do PORs and Internships matter?
questions.answer: Research internships help. PORs don’t matter much but can be a plus. My self-projects and consistent AI/ML focus helped.

questions.question: When did you start preparing for CDC? What was your preparation process like?
questions.answer: I started in the summer break. Focused first on DSA, then domain-specific prep in AI/ML.

questions.question: How did you prepare for the interviews?
questions.answer: Didn't prepare separately. I knew my domain well and was confident in answering. It’s important to know your CV and communicate clearly.

questions.question: Domain knowledge requirements.
questions.answer: For ML: supervised/unsupervised learning, math background, Python implementation. Best way to learn is through projects.

questions.question: How much DSA is required?
questions.answer: Decent DSA is needed for screening. Focus on Leetcode easy/medium, consistently practiced.

questions.question: How much of CS fundamentals are required?
questions.answer: Not needed for NPCI, but I prepared via Striver’s TUF.

questions.question: Could you share some resources for preparation?
questions.answer: DSA: Leetcode, Codeforces, Striver’s sheet. ML: hands-on Python projects, Kaggle, blogs (machinelearningmastery.com), YT: Sentdex, CampusX, Krish Naik.

questions.question: What is a good CV in your opinion?
questions.answer: Focus on numbers and results. Be crisp. Highlight important words. Accuracy, impact, outcomes > generic statements.

questions.question: What was your backup profile?
questions.answer: SDE. DSA helped for this.

questions.question: With only a month in hand, what should one focus on? Should one have any target companies?
questions.answer: If you have good CG (8.5+), target specific companies. Else, focus on preparation, especially problem solving.

questions.question: Any extra tips?
questions.answer: Don’t get distracted by others’ offers. Focus. Prepare in groups. Stay consistent with revision and be chill. All the best!

tips: Start early with DSA — it’s essential for all roles.
Be consistent and confident about your domain.
Group study helps; don’t compare progress with others.
Projects teach best — go beyond tutorials and blogs.

title: Cracking Core Roles: A CDC Journey into Reliance Industries
author: Anshuman Sahoo
summary: Reliance core intern with focused prep on corrosion and welding. Selected via OA and interview based on CV and project work. Emphasized early prep, honest CVs, and using summer for internships or research.

questions.question: Hello! Today we have with us a core intern at Reliance Industries Limited, who is currently pursuing a B.Tech in Metallurgical and Materials Engineering. Let’s hear about their CDC experience and preparation journey. Thank you for joining us!
questions.answer: Thank you! Glad to be here.

questions.question: Can you briefly describe your CDC experience and how the selection process went for Reliance?
questions.answer: My CDC experience was great. For Reliance, the selection involved one Online Assessment (OA) round and one combined Technical and HR interview round. In the OA round, we were given 50 questions from core subjects and 50 aptitude questions, to be solved in a total of 2 hours. In the interview, questions were asked directly from my CV. I had mentioned a research internship and an ML project related to metallurgy, so the questions were mainly around those. Some examples included: What was the purpose of your project? What were its final results? Why did you choose this method for finding the grain size? There were also subject-specific questions from Corrosion like - Which grain is more resistant to corrosion: coarser or finer? When is a grain called coarser or finer (in terms of size)?

questions.question: Did you face any challenges being from the MME department? How do CGPA, PORs, and internships matter?
questions.answer: Yes, as an MME student, if you're targeting software companies, your CV needs to be especially strong. Different companies have different selection styles — some give weightage to the OA score, while others prefer a strong CV regardless of OA performance. In general: PORs don’t matter much for software or core roles. CGPA does play a role, especially for core companies and a few software ones. Internships are definitely beneficial — they give you practical exposure and differentiate you from others.

questions.question: Did you face any challenges as a student from the Metallurgical and Materials Engineering department?
questions.answer: Yes, to some extent. There is some department bias — for example, TATA Steel didn’t open for us, even though it’s a core company. But honestly, if you’re skilled and patient, you’ll find opportunities. I wanted a core role but wasn’t sure I would get one, so I also prepared for other profiles. I even learned DSA, which I feel is important for everyone — it sharpens your problem-solving ability. Regarding CGPA, while many companies don’t have a hard cutoff, those with limited slots tend to shortlist higher CGs first. A CG above 8.3–8.5 is generally safe.

questions.question: When did you start preparing and what was your approach?
questions.answer: I started preparing in May, just after my 2nd year ended. I was doing a research internship at that time and simultaneously worked on a few self-projects to enhance my CV.

questions.question: How did you prepare for your interview at Reliance?
questions.answer: For Reliance, I focused deeply on two key subjects: Corrosion and Welding. I revised all the class notes and made sure I understood both topics conceptually and practically.

questions.question: Are the department lectures enough to prepare for core company interviews?
questions.answer: Absolutely. For subjects like Corrosion and Welding, the classroom content is more than sufficient. Just paying attention in class and understanding what’s taught gives you a strong foundation.

questions.question: How should students utilize their summer break?
questions.answer: Summer breaks are a great time to gain experience. You can: Apply for internships in core companies, Pursue a research internship under a professor, it adds significant value to your CV.

questions.question: In your opinion, what makes a good CV?
questions.answer: A good CV shows relevant experience. If you're applying for a core role, your CV should clearly reflect some exposure in that domain — through internships, projects, or research.

questions.question: Any suggestions on how to approach people for internships?
questions.answer: Cold mailing is very effective. Reach out to professors or companies with short, clear, and polite messages. Don’t get discouraged if you don’t get replies immediately — keep trying

questions.question: What was your backup profile?
questions.answer: My backup plan was applying for software roles. I had done some preparation in DSA and general programming in case I didn’t make it into a core company.

questions.question: Any final suggestions for students targeting core roles?
questions.answer: Yes — focus primarily on Corrosion and Welding, as they are frequently asked in core interviews. For Metallurgy students, companies like Bajaj, Vedanta, JSW, and Reliance are ideal core targets.

tips: Start preparing early – ideally by the summer after your second year.
Focus on key subjects like Corrosion and Welding if you are targeting core roles.
Keep your CV honest and experience-focused — don’t add projects or work you haven’t actually done.
Apply actively through cold emails for internships and research roles.

title: Navigating CDC with Confidence: Navpreet’s Vedanta Internship Experience in Core Metallurgy
author: Navpreet Singh Ghai
summary: In this interview, Navpreet shares his CDC internship journey, detailing his selection process and role at Vedanta's Hindustan Zinc Limited. Although the role was listed under “Strategy and Business,” his work focused on core metallurgy, especially in lead blast furnace operations. He discusses interview preparation, the importance of extractive metallurgy, test strategies, and balancing multiple interests like machine learning and core. Navpreet emphasizes the value of building a strong profile, staying confident, and being patient through the CDC process.

questions.question: Hello Navpreet! Let’s begin. Could you tell us about the offer you received through CDC? What’s your role and where are you posted?
questions.answer: Sure! I got an offer from Vedanta, listed on the CDC portal under “Strategy and Business.” But in reality, the role is entirely core metallurgy. I’ve been placed at Hindustan Zinc Limited under Vedanta. Specifically, I’m working in the lead blast furnace section, focusing on the secondary furnace used in the lead extraction process.

questions.question: Interesting! And how long is the internship?
questions.answer: It’s a two-month internship.

questions.question: Could you walk us through your CDC process and how you got selected?
questions.answer: Of course. It started with a test—very simple and not technical at all. It was mostly HR-style, situation-based questions like “how would you respond to a senior in a tough situation” or “this or that” type questions. No core or technical MCQs. It was a 1-hour test, but I finished it much quicker. Based on our test performance and CV, the Vedanta Jharsuguda team shortlisted students.

questions.question: And how did your interview go?
questions.answer: I had a fair idea of the process from seniors in the previous batch, so I was well prepared. The questions were mostly from extractive metallurgy. They asked which metals I was confident in—aluminium, copper, lead, zinc—and I chose aluminium. Then they asked me to walk them through the reaction sequence for aluminium extraction, which I did. They also asked about my industrial exposure, and I mentioned growing up in the UltraTech Cement colony (Aditya Birla Group). I’ve seen plant operations and furnaces up close. This led to questions on types of furnaces and their parts, and later we discussed iron and copper extraction sequences.

questions.question: Did they ask any HR questions?
questions.answer: Yes, quite a few. They asked about tight deadlines, odd working hours, and whether I’d be okay working outside 9-to-5. Since I’ve seen similar environments growing up, I was very honest and confident in my answers. They also asked tricky questions like “If you had to choose between us and Aditya Birla, what would you pick and why?” I responded diplomatically and kept it balanced.

questions.question: When did all this take place?
questions.answer: Around the last week of October. The application opened mid-October, followed by the test and then the interviews. Everything was conducted online via Zoom.

questions.question: Were all the interview questions purely technical?
questions.answer: Mostly. They focused on non-ferrous extractive metallurgy—nothing too deep, but you needed to be confident with the basics.

questions.question: Do you have any advice for future metallurgy interns?
questions.answer: Yes—focus on extractive metallurgy. You don’t need to dive into niche topics like corrosion, transport phenomena, or steel-making unless the job role specifies it. Just have a strong grasp of surface-level concepts and explain them clearly. Impressing the interviewer matters more than covering every subject.

questions.question: Did you have any prior internships?
questions.answer: Yes, and I mentioned them in the interview. I did a remote internship as a financial analyst with a biotech startup called AuroBio. I prepared investment summaries, and the company worked on microbial waste management through fermentation. This helped demonstrate that I’m genuinely interested in core and interdisciplinary work. I also did a research internship in second year at IIT Kharagpur, under the Centre of Excellence in Advanced Manufacturing Technologies, where I worked on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs).

questions.question: What about PoRs (Positions of Responsibility)?
questions.answer: They didn’t ask much about it. But PoRs can definitely help if you don’t have strong internships or projects.

questions.question: How did you prepare your CV?
questions.answer: I started about a week before the portal opened. I listed all my achievements, collected certificates, and wrote draft pointers under internships, projects, and co-curriculars. I took feedback from seniors after every draft. One useful tip: avoid overusing words like “spearheaded.” Also, be ready for formatting issues. The CDC portal glitched and changed my font size before the final submission—so always double-check.

questions.question: Did having those extra internships and projects help?
questions.answer: Definitely. Having a mix of core and tech/ML projects gives you an edge. For instance, my batchmate Anushka was even asked about SVMs (Support Vector Machines) in her interview. Such things make you stand out.

questions.question: What was your main profile target—data, core, or something else?
questions.answer: Initially, I was aiming for ML/Data roles, and most of my shortlists were in that domain.

questions.question: Any general tips for building a good profile?
questions.answer: Yes—start early. Focus on building solid sections in your CV: education, internships, projects, achievements, PoRs. If you’re missing something, create it. Watch YouTube, learn something like web dev, and build a mini project to fill the gap. Make every section meaningful.

questions.question: What if someone has just one project and no internship?
questions.answer: That’s fine—highlight the project well. Do some certifications. Ask your friends for learning-based internship certificates (if you actually learned from them). Just be sure you can defend everything on your CV.

questions.question: Any suggestions about target companies?
questions.answer: For July tests, play to your strengths. If you’re targeting SDE or data, focus on DSA. For consulting or product, prep for case studies. HR questions don’t require much preparation—just be clear and confident.

questions.question: Should students keep core as a backup?
questions.answer: Absolutely. If a core company visits, just apply. You’ve got nothing to lose. You don’t need to study all subjects in advance—just prep well once the company opens.

questions.question: Do test performances matter more than the CV?
questions.answer: In most cases, yes. A great test score can get you shortlisted even with an average CV. Try to solve at least 2 full DSA problems and get around 80% accuracy.

questions.question: How do you manage remote proctored tests?
questions.answer: You can use a second screen. Sometimes friends join via Google Meet or Discord to help with moral support. Just note that some companies like Accenture are very strict. If you’re caught, you won’t get shortlisted, but you won’t be blacklisted either.

questions.question: What if CDC shifts to offline testing?
questions.answer: That might happen only if the semester is offline. In that case, tests would likely happen in Nalanda classrooms.

questions.question: Any final advice for first and second-year students?
questions.answer: Be patient. It’s a difficult process. Sometimes deserving people don’t get selected, and less deserving ones do—it happens. Luck matters. But if you stay consistent and put in your efforts, something good will come. Also, don’t isolate yourself—participate in campus life, take up responsibilities. Handling many things at once builds real confidence, and that’s a game-changer when you enter the industry.

questions.question: That’s incredibly insightful, Navpreet. Thank you so much for sharing your experience!
questions.answer: Thank you! I hope it helps someone.

tips: Master Extractive Metallurgy – Focus on aluminium, copper, zinc, and lead for core roles.
Ace the Test – Strong test scores often matter more than your CV.
Diversify Your Profile – Combine core and tech/ML projects to stand out.
Prepare CV Early – Start early and fill all sections meaningfully.

title: CDC Internship Journey and Preparation Tips from an MME Student at IIT Kharagpur - Apurva Ninave
author: Apurva Ninave
summary: An MME student from IIT Kharagpur shares their CDC internship experience, highlighting interview rounds, challenges faced, and preparation strategies. The discussion includes tips on building a strong CV, utilizing summer breaks, and staying focused during the final month.

questions.question: Could you introduce yourself and describe your CDC experience?
questions.answer: I’m a student from the Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering (MME), IIT Kharagpur. I recently participated in the CDC internship process and secured a core internship. The process began early in the morning with interviews starting around 10:00 AM. There were two rounds — a technical round followed by an HR round. The technical round lasted 25–30 minutes and covered core metallurgy topics like phase transformations, heat treatment, corrosion, recrystallization, and grain growth. The HR round lasted around 15 minutes and focused on questions about strengths, weaknesses, and interest in the company.

questions.question: What challenges did you face as an MME student during the CDC process?
questions.answer: One major challenge is that many companies only open for circuital branches. Additionally, companies often set CGPA cutoffs (7.5 or 8.0), making it crucial to maintain a good academic record. While PoRs help in consulting roles, their relevance to the applied role is important. Internships in the related field can give a significant edge. In some interviews like Bajaj, CGPA and PoRs didn’t matter much — skills and technical depth did.

questions.question: When did you start preparing for CDC, and what was your process like?
questions.answer: I started with projects in relevant domains, which helped strengthen my CV. Later, I pursued a summer internship that provided real-world experience. This combination of projects and internship helped build a strong profile for CDC.

questions.question: How did you prepare for your interviews?
questions.answer: I got to know about my interview just a night before. I immediately contacted seniors who had interned at Bajaj, and they shared important topics to focus on. I revised those topics thoroughly and ensured my CV was well-prepared and polished.

questions.question: What resources did you use for CDC preparation?
questions.answer: I used my class notes and PDFs shared by professors. I recommend utilizing the summer break by pursuing internships or doing relevant projects. Setting up a timeline can help stay on track.

questions.question: What makes a good CV in your opinion?
questions.answer: A good CV includes real-time projects, relevant coursework and skills, and internships. CGPA alone doesn’t reflect someone’s ability — even with a lower CGPA, one can perform well in interviews if they have the right skills.

questions.question: How can students approach companies or professors for internships?
questions.answer: Students can reach out to startup founders on LinkedIn and share their CVs. Other platforms like Wellfound and Glassdoor are also useful. Also, keep an eye on internship emails from the PR Chair. For research internships, cold mailing professors is a great approach.

questions.question: Did you have a backup profile?
questions.answer: Yes, my backup profile was Software Development (SDE).

questions.question: What should students focus on if only a month is left before CDC?
questions.answer: Focus on revision rather than trying to add new projects. Identify a few target companies or profiles and tailor your preparation toward those. It’s all about focused study and consistent revision at that point.

questions.question: How important are departmental courses for core placements?
questions.answer: They are extremely important. Core technical interviews are based heavily on departmental subjects. A solid grasp of these subjects is crucial.

questions.question: Did you do any research internships or projects before CDC?
questions.answer: Yes, I did a research internship, although it wasn’t directly relevant to the core field. So it didn’t contribute much to my CDC selection.

questions.question: Do dual degree students have an advantage over B.Tech students?
questions.answer: Yes, especially in core companies. Dual degree students are often preferred over B.Tech students.

questions.question: Any final tips or advice you’d like to share?
questions.answer: Don’t rush your preparation and don’t lose hope if you don’t get a shortlist early on. Keep working hard — if your preparation is good, you’ll eventually get selected either through CDC or off-campus. Luck plays a part, but consistent effort matters more. Set target companies, build a strong profile, and seek help from seniors.

tips: Use the summer to build solid projects or gain internship experience.
Talk to seniors who interned at your target companies — their guidance is invaluable.
Revise departmental subjects well — they are the backbone of core interviews.
Stay consistent and don’t panic if things don’t go your way initially.

title: Cracking CDC: Tips to Boost Your Shortlists and Stand Out
author: Sharwari Muley
summary: The intern shares their CDC journey at Vedanta Ltd. through the VLDP GET program, highlighting a mix of technical and data-driven responsibilities. The selection involved a psychometric test and an interview focused on core metallurgy and resume-based questions. Key takeaways include early preparation, building strong projects, maintaining a good CGPA, and staying open to both tech and core roles. Consistency and seeking guidance from seniors played a crucial role in securing the offer.

questions.question: Hi! Thank you for joining us today. To start off, could you briefly describe your current role at Vedanta?
questions.answer: Sure! I received a CDC internship offer from Vedanta Ltd. under the VLDP GET internship—which stands for Vedanta Leadership Development Programme Graduate Engineer Trainee. This role is usually open to students from core departments like CH, MT, MI, and GG. Around 6–7 students from our department are selected every year. Though the position is fundamentally technical, interns—especially from IITs—are often entrusted with projects focused on optimization and data-driven analysis. Given my interest and experience in data, I was assigned a project involving data analysis and optimization, allowing me to apply my skills beyond conventional core work.

questions.question: That’s great! Can you walk us through your CDC experience—the online assessments and the interview?
questions.answer: The selection process consisted of one online test followed by a single interview round. The test primarily included psychometric questions and some multiple-choice questions related to core topics. The interview was a mix of technical and HR questions. On the technical side, they asked about: Ferrous and non-ferrous metals, Electrorefining, electrowinning, Hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, and leaching They also asked me to choose a favourite subject and probed deeper into that. Extraction processes of copper and zinc were discussed too. Since my CV leaned towards a data profile, I was also asked about my technical skills, projects, and past internships. The HR part included questions like 'Why do you want to join Vedanta?' and 'What value can you bring to this role?' The entire interview lasted around 35–40 minutes and was conducted online.

questions.question: As a student from MME, did you face any specific challenges in terms of shortlisting?
questions.answer: Yes, to an extent. Many companies are biased toward circuital branches, but some still open for all departments. Personally, I got 4–5 shortlists from tech companies, but Vedanta was my first core shortlist. Students from our department often have to put in more effort, but consistent hard work does pay off. While core roles may be limited, this company stands out as it specifically considers candidates from MME. Even if you're not keen on a core role, I’d still recommend applying for this position—the work is not entirely core and is a solid opportunity. A CGPA above 7.5 helps with shortlisting, and having core-related projects or research internships definitely strengthens your profile.

questions.question: How important are PORs and internships for this role?
questions.answer: They do add value, especially to demonstrate involvement and past experience. But not having formal internships isn’t a major disadvantage. Self-initiated projects or research work in core areas are equally valuable and can make your application stand out.

questions.question: When did you begin your CDC prep? What was your approach?
questions.answer: I started in April, focusing mainly on Data and SDE profiles, while keeping Core as a backup. I practiced: DSA, Python, ML concepts And worked on relevant projects aligned with those domains. But honestly, DSA practice should be started earlier for better grip. If you’re targeting a company like Vedanta, definitely revise core metallurgy concepts and refer to interview questions from previous years.

questions.question: How did you specifically prepare for the interviews?
questions.answer: I followed a multi-step approach: Reading blogs, Taking mock interviews, Talking to seniors Also, I focused on company-specific topics that are repeatedly asked in interviews. All of this gave me confidence and clarity during the actual process.

questions.question: How much do departmental courses matter for this role?
questions.answer: They matter a lot. Most of the interview questions were department-specific. For MME students, topics like metal extraction are especially important, and they were heavily emphasized in my interview.

questions.question: Did you have any prior internships or projects before CDC? How did they help?
questions.answer: Yes, I had: One research internship, One corporate internship, And a few self-initiated projects These experiences gave my CV practical depth, helping me get shortlists. Companies often discuss past work during interviews, so these internships definitely helped in demonstrating my abilities.

questions.question: Do you think Dual Degree students have an advantage in core shortlisting?
questions.answer: Generally, yes—especially for core roles. In our department, the shortlist ratio for Vedanta was about 70% Dual:30% B.Tech, and I was the only B.Tech student to receive an offer from the company.

questions.question: With just one month left before CDC, what should students focus on?
questions.answer: With a month left, I suggest: Focus on impactful projects for your target profile, Practice DSA regularly, Go through previous interview/test questions, Prepare your CV early and get it reviewed by seniors. Also, stay in touch with seniors—they offer valuable guidance. And most importantly, don’t give up. CDC is a mix of skills and luck, and it doesn’t define your worth. Stay consistent, give your best in every opportunity, and stay positive—your effort will pay off.

tips: Start Early – Begin DSA, Python, and ML prep in advance.
Build Projects – Strong projects can boost your CV even without formal internships.
Use Senior Help – Get your CV reviewed and give mock interviews.
Stay Open-Minded – Apply for both tech and core roles like Vedanta’s hybrid profile.

title: From Consulting Aspirant to Core Convert: A CDC Journey into Vedanta
author: Rashmita Sahoo
summary: In this interview, a Metallurgical and Materials Engineering student shares their CDC internship journey, culminating in a core internship offer from Vedanta. Initially targeting consulting roles, they later pivoted to core based on shifting shortlisting criteria. They discuss their preparation strategy, including leveraging core coursework, literature reviews, and mentorship from seniors. The student highlights challenges like limited openings for MME students, emphasizes the importance of CGPA and projects, and offers practical tips on interview prep, cold emailing, and making the most of summer breaks.

questions.question: Hello! Today we have with us a core intern at Vedanta, who is currently pursuing dual degree course in Metallurgical and Materials Engineering. Let’s hear about their CDC experience and preparation journey. Thank you for joining us!
questions.answer: Thank you! Glad to be here.

questions.question: How was your CDC experience? Any memorable questions?
questions.answer: Overall, it was a good experience. For Vedanta, the process began with a psychometric test followed by a technical interview. The interview questions were highly core-focused. They asked about powder metallurgy — concepts like compaction, sintering, density, green density, and also about tempering. Since Vedanta’s profile is completely core-oriented, they expected a solid understanding of such topics.

questions.question: Did you face any challenges as an MME student in terms of CV shortlisting?
questions.answer: Yes, many companies don’t open for metallurgy students. They often allow only circuital branches. But if you have the right skills, you can still apply to those open for us. Companies like Amazon, for example, did accept us. For consulting firms like BCG or McKinsey, CGPA becomes very important — usually above 8 or 8.5.

questions.question: When did you begin preparing, and what was your strategy?
questions.answer: Preparation depends on the profile. For core roles, past coursework and projects help a lot. For consulting and data, I’d suggest beginning at least six months in advance. I initially aimed for consulting — got shortlisted by Kepler Cannon but missed the interview due to travel. Later, I shifted focus to core because of changing criteria and my background. Understanding company-specific work helps. For Vedanta, I studied aluminium production and metallurgy concepts like ductility vs strength — and how tempering can balance both.

questions.question: How did you prepare for the interview?
questions.answer: I consulted seniors for common HR and technical questions. There’s a useful HR question bank of ~60 questions. For technical preparation, I revised extraction processes for iron, aluminium, zinc — especially topics relevant to Vedanta. Seniors helped me with mock interviews too.

questions.question: What preparation do you suggest during summer breaks?
questions.answer: If not doing an internship, work under a department professor. Core-related projects, literature reviews, or even projects at IISc, DMRL, or DRDO are great. A decent CGPA (7.5+) is important. Reading research papers in your domain of interest and summarizing them for your CV also adds value.

questions.question: What does a strong CV look like to you?
questions.answer: A good CGPA (7.5+), and strong core-related projects — especially under reputed professors or institutes. For consulting, a high CGPA, achievements in Inter-IITs, or winning case study competitions matter. Relevant projects are critical for data roles.

questions.question: How should students approach off-campus internships?
questions.answer: Cold emailing is key. Reach out to professors with a solid cover letter and resume. Look for openings on portals of IITs, IISc, DRDO, IOCL, etc. Many offer summer internships — stay alert. Express genuine interest in their research area.

questions.question: What was your backup plan?
questions.answer: Initially, consulting was the primary focus due to my multiple PoRs. But I eventually shifted to core after shortlisting trends changed and aligned more with my academic background.

questions.question: With a month left before CDC, what should one focus on?
questions.answer: Revise past coursework and projects. Be interview-ready for every project mentioned in your CV. If targeting consulting — practice guesstimates and case studies. Talk to seniors for company-specific preparation.

questions.question: How important are departmental courses for core roles?
questions.answer: They matter a lot in metallurgy-based roles. For materials science, our department has fewer courses, so that can be a limitation — but opportunities still exist.

questions.question: Did you need extra preparation for core roles?
questions.answer: Not much. If your basics are clear and you’ve done 2–3 good core projects (even a DIY one counts), you’re set. Don’t overdo it — just focus on fundamentals and application.

questions.question: Any projects or research before CDC?
questions.answer: I worked on a research project with Stanford — not core-specific, but still valuable. Also had coursework projects that I included in my CV.

questions.question: Do dual-degree students have an advantage?
questions.answer: Yes, they usually do — more experience, more courses, and an extra year for research/internship exposure.

questions.question: Any interdisciplinary advantages?
questions.answer: Absolutely. For data roles or finance (especially EPs), interdisciplinary knowledge helps a lot. It adds flexibility and opens up more options.

tips: Go to classes and focus on fundamentals.
Take up projects early — under professors or at reputed institutions.
Maintain a good CGPA (8.5+ for consulting).
For data, practice ML and DL regularly.
Be versatile — show multitasking ability, especially for consult profiles.
Don’t ignore literature reviews — they add serious weight to your CV.
